Clinical Supervision Policy

Professional Standards and Clinical Governance

Policy Information

Policy Owner: Clinical Director

Effective Date: January 2025

Review Date: January 2026

Version: 1.0

CQC Regulation: Supports Regulation 12 (Safe care and treatment) and Regulation 17 (Good governance)

Applies To: All clinical staff, therapists, and supervisors

1. Policy Statement

ClearMinds is committed to providing high-quality, safe, and effective therapeutic services. Clinical supervision is central to this commitment, ensuring that all therapists receive regular, structured support to maintain professional standards, develop competence, and safeguard service users.

This policy establishes the framework for clinical supervision at ClearMinds, ensuring compliance with professional body requirements (BACP, UKCP, NCH) and CQC expectations for clinical governance and quality assurance.

Purpose of Clinical Supervision

Clinical supervision serves three essential functions:

  • Normative: Quality assurance, professional accountability, adherence to standards and ethics
  • Formative: Professional development, skill enhancement, reflective practice
  • Restorative: Emotional support, prevention of burnout, therapist wellbeing

Effective supervision protects service users, supports therapists, and maintains organisational quality standards.

2. Scope and Application

2.1 Who Must Receive Supervision?

All clinical staff providing therapy or hypnotherapy services at ClearMinds must receive regular clinical supervision, including:

  • Fully qualified therapists and hypnotherapists
  • Trainee and newly qualified practitioners
  • Supervisors themselves (receiving supervision from another qualified supervisor)
  • Clinical Director (peer supervision or external supervision)

No exceptions: Supervision is mandatory regardless of experience level or professional seniority.

2.2 Types of Supervision at ClearMinds

  • Individual supervision: One-to-one sessions with designated supervisor (primary model)
  • Group supervision: Small group of therapists with qualified supervisor (supplementary or alternative)
  • Peer supervision: Collaborative supervision among experienced practitioners (not replacement for formal supervision unless both parties qualified supervisors)
  • Line management supervision: Separate from clinical supervision; focuses on performance, operational matters

Important distinction: Clinical supervision is separate from line management. While Clinical Director may provide both, the roles and boundaries must be clear.

3. Supervision Requirements and Frequency

3.1 Mandatory Frequency Standards

Practitioner Level Minimum Frequency Format
Trainee/Student therapist Fortnightly (every 2 weeks) Individual supervision (1 hour minimum)
Newly qualified (first 2 years post-qualification) Fortnightly (every 2 weeks) Individual supervision (1 hour minimum)
Qualified practitioner (2+ years post-qualification) Monthly (minimum) Individual or group supervision (1.5 hours minimum per month)
Experienced practitioner (5+ years) Monthly (minimum) Individual, group, or peer supervision (1.5 hours minimum per month)
Clinical supervisors Monthly (minimum) Supervision of supervision (with external or peer supervisor)

3.2 Supervision Ratio (Caseload)

Professional bodies recommend supervision in proportion to clinical contact hours:

  • BACP guidance: 1.5 hours supervision per month minimum for practitioners seeing clients
  • High caseload (20+ client contact hours/week): Consider increasing to 2 hours supervision per month
  • Complex cases or high-risk work: Additional ad-hoc supervision as needed

3.3 Additional Supervision

Beyond mandatory scheduled supervision, therapists should access additional support when:

  • Managing high-risk cases (suicide risk, safeguarding concerns, complex trauma)
  • Experiencing ethical dilemmas or professional uncertainty
  • Feeling emotionally impacted by client work
  • Involved in complaints, incidents, or challenging situations
  • Working with new client populations or therapeutic modalities

Therapists can request additional supervision sessions at any time. This is encouraged and will not be viewed negatively.

4. Supervisor Qualifications and Standards

4.1 Supervisor Requirements

Clinical supervisors at ClearMinds must meet the following criteria:

Minimum Supervisor Qualifications

  • Qualified therapist/counsellor: Hold recognised qualification (BACP accredited, UKCP registered, or equivalent)
  • Substantial clinical experience: Minimum 5 years post-qualification practice (or as per professional body requirements)
  • Supervision training: Completed recognised supervision training course (minimum 30 hours or equivalent to Certificate level)
  • Current practice: Maintain active clinical practice (not solely supervision)
  • Professional registration: Current registration with professional body (BACP, UKCP, NCH)
  • Ongoing supervision: Receive supervision for their supervision practice
  • CPD: Engage in continuing professional development relevant to supervision
  • Professional insurance: Hold appropriate professional indemnity insurance covering supervision

4.2 Supervisor Accreditation

ClearMinds encourages supervisors to pursue professional accreditation as supervisors through:

  • BACP Accredited Supervisor status
  • UKCP Registered Supervisor status
  • Equivalent recognised professional accreditation

4.3 Internal vs External Supervisors

ClearMinds uses both internal and external supervisors:

  • Internal supervisors: Clinical Director and senior therapists who meet supervisor requirements
  • External supervisors: Independent supervisors contracted to provide supervision (particularly for supervisors themselves, or for modality-specific supervision)

Independence consideration: Where supervisor has management responsibility for supervisee, boundaries must be clearly managed. External supervision option available if preferred.

5. The Supervision Contract

5.1 Written Supervision Agreement

Each supervision relationship must be formalised through a written supervision contract/agreement covering:

Supervision Contract Contents

  • Practical arrangements: Frequency, duration, location/format (in-person, video), fees (if external supervisor)
  • Responsibilities: Supervisor and supervisee roles and expectations
  • Boundaries: Distinction between clinical supervision and line management
  • Confidentiality: Limits and exceptions (safeguarding, fitness to practise, organisational requirements)
  • Records: Who keeps records, what is documented, retention period
  • Review and evaluation: How effectiveness of supervision will be reviewed
  • Cancellation and absence: Notice periods, rescheduling, missed sessions
  • Ending supervision: Process for planned or unplanned endings
  • Complaints: How to raise concerns about supervision
  • Professional frameworks: Reference to professional codes of ethics and ClearMinds policies

5.2 Review of Supervision Arrangements

Supervision contracts and relationships should be reviewed:

  • After initial 3 months (settling-in review)
  • Annually (formal review and renewal of contract)
  • When significant changes occur (role change, caseload increase, new challenges)
  • If concerns arise from either party

6. Content and Focus of Supervision

6.1 What Should Be Discussed in Supervision?

Supervision sessions should address:

Area Content
Case discussion Review of client work, therapeutic interventions, progress, challenges, formulation
Risk assessment and management Safeguarding concerns, suicide risk, harm to others, duty of care
Ethical dilemmas Boundary issues, dual relationships, confidentiality dilemmas, professional conduct
Therapeutic relationship Transference/countertransference, therapeutic alliance, ruptures and repairs
Therapist wellbeing Impact of client work, vicarious trauma, burnout prevention, self-care
Skill development Technique refinement, new modalities, areas for growth, CPD planning
Professional practice Record-keeping, consent, policies, organisational requirements
Diversity and difference Cultural competence, working with difference, addressing bias

6.2 Reflective Practice

Supervision must include reflective practice – examining not just what happened, but:

  • Why did I respond that way?
  • What was I feeling during the session?
  • What assumptions or biases might I have?
  • What could I have done differently?
  • What does this tell me about my practice?
  • What do I need to develop or learn?

6.3 Mandatory Supervision Topics

The following must be discussed in supervision as they arise:

  • Safeguarding concerns: All safeguarding issues must be discussed in supervision (or immediately if urgent)
  • High-risk cases: Clients at risk of suicide, self-harm, harm to others
  • Complaints or concerns: Any complaints about therapist or service
  • Ethical dilemmas: When uncertain about right course of action
  • Boundary crossings or violations: Any boundary issues
  • Therapist distress: If therapist struggling emotionally or personally

Urgent Issues – Do Not Wait for Next Supervision

For immediate safeguarding concerns, imminent risk, or crisis situations:

  • Contact Clinical Director immediately (same day)
  • Follow ClearMinds Safeguarding and Risk Management policies
  • Arrange emergency supervision session if needed
  • Document actions taken and supervision sought

Scheduled supervision should never be a barrier to accessing urgent support.

7. Supervision Records and Documentation

7.1 Supervisor Responsibilities

Supervisors must maintain records of supervision sessions including:

  • Date and duration of supervision
  • Supervisee name
  • Attendance record (attended, cancelled, DNA)
  • Brief summary of topics discussed (sufficient detail to demonstrate supervision occurred)
  • Cases discussed (anonymised or initials only)
  • Risk issues identified and actions agreed
  • Learning objectives or development areas
  • Supervisor's reflections and any concerns

7.2 Supervisee Responsibilities

Therapists must maintain their own supervision log/record including:

  • Date, duration, and supervisor name
  • Summary of topics discussed and learning points
  • Actions arising from supervision
  • Reflection on how supervision supported practice
  • Cumulative record of supervision hours (for professional registration)

7.3 Confidentiality of Supervision Records

Supervision records are confidential with the following exceptions:

  • Safeguarding concerns: Must be escalated and documented in organisational systems
  • Fitness to practise concerns: If supervisor has serious concerns about therapist's competence or conduct, Clinical Director must be informed
  • Legal requirements: Court orders, regulatory investigations
  • Audit and CQC inspection: Evidence of supervision may be reviewed (personal/sensitive details redacted)

7.4 Organisational Oversight

To ensure supervision is occurring consistently, ClearMinds maintains:

  • Register of all therapists and their assigned supervisors
  • Attendance log for supervision sessions
  • Annual supervision audits to confirm compliance
  • Supervision evaluation feedback

8. Responsibilities and Accountability

8.1 Supervisee (Therapist) Responsibilities

  • Attend all scheduled supervision sessions (or provide reasonable notice if unable)
  • Prepare for supervision by reflecting on practice and identifying topics
  • Engage actively and honestly in supervision process
  • Bring challenging cases, ethical dilemmas, and safeguarding concerns
  • Implement agreed actions and report back on outcomes
  • Maintain supervision records and evidence CPD
  • Raise concerns about supervision if not meeting needs
  • Ensure supervision arrangements meet professional body requirements

8.2 Supervisor Responsibilities

  • Provide regular, reliable supervision as per contract
  • Create safe, confidential, non-judgmental supervision space
  • Monitor supervisee's practice for safety, competence, and ethical conduct
  • Challenge practice that raises concerns
  • Support supervisee's professional development and wellbeing
  • Maintain clear boundaries between supervision, therapy, and management
  • Maintain accurate supervision records
  • Escalate serious concerns (safeguarding, fitness to practise) appropriately
  • Engage in own supervision of supervision practice
  • Maintain professional competence through CPD

8.3 Clinical Director Responsibilities

  • Ensure all therapists have access to appropriate supervision
  • Monitor supervision attendance and compliance
  • Approve and quality-assure supervisors (internal and external)
  • Provide organisational support for supervision (funding, time, resources)
  • Review supervision effectiveness through feedback and audit
  • Address concerns about supervision quality or non-compliance
  • Ensure supervision integrated with clinical governance framework

8.4 Organisational Accountability

ClearMinds is ultimately accountable for:

  • Quality and safety of services provided to service users
  • Professional competence and conduct of employed therapists
  • Provision of adequate supervision systems
  • Compliance with professional and regulatory standards

9. Safeguarding and Fitness to Practise

9.1 Supervision's Role in Safeguarding

Clinical supervision is a key safeguarding mechanism:

  • Provides oversight of safeguarding decision-making and actions
  • Ensures safeguarding concerns are appropriately identified and responded to
  • Supports therapists to manage complex safeguarding situations
  • Monitors ongoing safeguarding cases

9.2 Escalating Concerns in Supervision

If a supervisor has concerns about a supervisee's fitness to practise, they must:

Fitness to Practise Concerns

Supervisors must escalate to Clinical Director if they have concerns about:

  • Competence: Therapist lacking skills or knowledge to work safely
  • Ethical conduct: Boundary violations, breaches of confidentiality, misconduct
  • Health and wellbeing: Therapist's own mental health, substance use, or personal issues affecting ability to practise safely
  • Impaired judgment: Consistently poor clinical decision-making despite supervision input
  • Non-engagement: Repeatedly missing supervision, refusing to discuss concerns, defensive responses

Action: Document concerns, discuss with supervisee (if appropriate), escalate to Clinical Director, follow organisational policies (capability, disciplinary, safeguarding).

9.3 Supervisee Self-Care and Wellbeing

Supervision should support therapist wellbeing by:

  • Monitoring signs of burnout, vicarious trauma, or compassion fatigue
  • Encouraging self-care and work-life balance
  • Normalising the emotional impact of client work
  • Signposting to additional support (personal therapy, occupational health, EAP)
  • Discussing caseload management and capacity

10. Group Supervision

10.1 When Group Supervision Is Appropriate

Group supervision can be effective as primary or supplementary supervision model. Benefits include:

  • Peer learning and diverse perspectives
  • Shared problem-solving
  • Cost-effectiveness
  • Reduction of isolation
  • Development of reflective practice culture

10.2 Group Supervision Requirements

  • Group size: Maximum 6 supervisees per supervisor
  • Duration: Minimum 2 hours per session to allow adequate time for each person
  • Frequency: As per individual supervision requirements (monthly minimum for qualified practitioners)
  • Group agreement: Clear ground rules on confidentiality, participation, respect
  • Individual allocation: Each therapist must have opportunity to present cases and receive feedback

10.3 Group Supervision Confidentiality

All group members must agree to maintain confidentiality of discussions. Supervisor must:

  • Establish clear confidentiality agreement at outset
  • Remind group of confidentiality expectations
  • Address any breaches immediately

11. Peer Supervision

11.1 Peer Supervision Defined

Peer supervision is collaborative supervision between practitioners of similar experience level. It can supplement (but not replace) formal supervision with a more experienced supervisor, unless both practitioners are qualified supervisors.

11.2 When Peer Supervision Is Acceptable

  • Experienced practitioners (5+ years): May use peer supervision as part of supervision portfolio
  • Qualified supervisors: Can provide reciprocal peer supervision to each other
  • Supplementary to formal supervision: Used alongside (not instead of) supervision with designated supervisor

11.3 Peer Supervision Structure

  • Clear agreement on arrangements (frequency, duration, responsibilities)
  • Equal participation from both parties
  • Structured format (not just informal chat)
  • Documentation of peer supervision
  • Acknowledgment of limitations (seek formal supervision for high-risk or complex cases)

12. Paying for External Supervision

12.1 ClearMinds Supervision Provision

ClearMinds provides:

  • Internal supervision: Free supervision with Clinical Director or designated internal supervisor
  • External supervision funding: Financial contribution towards external supervision if required (e.g., for modality-specific supervision, supervisor of supervisors)
  • Paid supervision time: Supervision time is part of contracted hours (not unpaid personal time)

12.2 External Supervision Arrangements

If therapist uses external supervisor:

  • Supervisor must meet ClearMinds approval criteria (qualifications, insurance, professional registration)
  • Supervision contract must be shared with Clinical Director
  • Attendance records must be provided to ClearMinds
  • ClearMinds may reimburse supervision fees up to agreed limit (as per employment contract)

13. Modality-Specific and Specialised Supervision

13.1 Hypnotherapy Supervision

Therapists providing hypnotherapy must receive supervision from a supervisor with hypnotherapy training and experience. This may be:

  • Internal supervisor with hypnotherapy qualification
  • External hypnotherapy-specific supervisor
  • Combination of generalist and specialist supervision

13.2 Other Specialist Supervision

Therapists working with specialist populations or modalities (e.g., trauma-focused therapy, EMDR, specialist populations) should seek supervision from someone with relevant expertise.

14. Supervision During Training and Probation

14.1 Trainee Therapists

  • Fortnightly supervision (1 hour minimum) with Clinical Director or nominated supervisor
  • Additional training supervision from course provider (if placement trainee)
  • Close monitoring of competence and readiness for independent practice
  • Clear learning objectives and developmental milestones

14.2 Newly Qualified Therapists

  • Fortnightly supervision in first year post-qualification
  • Structured induction and competency assessment
  • Gradual increase in caseload complexity
  • Regular review of progress and areas for development
  • Transition to monthly supervision after first year (if appropriate)

14.3 Probationary Period

All new therapists (regardless of experience) undergo probationary period with enhanced supervision to ensure:

  • Familiarisation with ClearMinds policies, procedures, and values
  • Competence in remote/virtual therapy delivery
  • Understanding of EAP model and workplace context
  • Confirmation of suitability for role

15. Continuing Professional Development (CPD)

15.1 CPD and Supervision

Supervision supports CPD by:

  • Identifying learning needs and development areas
  • Planning CPD activities aligned with practice needs
  • Reflecting on CPD undertaken and integrating learning into practice
  • Evidencing CPD for professional registration and revalidation

15.2 Supervision Counts as CPD

Supervision hours count towards professional body CPD requirements. Therapists should log supervision as CPD and reflect on learning gained.

16. Monitoring and Quality Assurance

16.1 Supervision Audit

ClearMinds conducts annual supervision audit to ensure:

  • All therapists receiving supervision at required frequency
  • Supervisors meet qualification and registration requirements
  • Supervision contracts in place and up to date
  • Records maintained appropriately
  • Safeguarding and risk issues appropriately discussed

16.2 Supervision Evaluation

Therapists complete annual supervision evaluation feedback covering:

  • Quality and effectiveness of supervision
  • Supervisor skills and approach
  • Whether supervision meets professional development needs
  • Impact of supervision on practice
  • Suggestions for improvement

Feedback reviewed by Clinical Director to identify themes and improvements.

16.3 Supervision and CQC Compliance

CQC expects providers to demonstrate:

  • Staff competency and suitability for role
  • Clinical governance and quality assurance systems
  • Supervision and support for staff
  • Learning and continuous improvement culture

Robust clinical supervision is key evidence for CQC compliance, particularly Regulations 12 (Safe care and treatment) and 17 (Good governance).

17. Concerns About Supervision

17.1 Raising Concerns

If a therapist has concerns about the supervision they are receiving, they should:

  1. Discuss with supervisor directly (if appropriate and feels safe to do so)
  2. Request change of supervisor (speak to Clinical Director)
  3. Raise formal concern (via HR or complaints process if serious)

Therapists will not be penalised for raising genuine concerns about supervision quality.

17.2 Supervisor Concerns About Supervisee

If supervisor has concerns about supervisee, they must:

  • Discuss concerns with supervisee directly (usually as first step)
  • Document concerns and actions agreed
  • Escalate to Clinical Director if concerns persist or are serious
  • Follow organisational capability, disciplinary, or safeguarding procedures as appropriate

18. Training for Supervisors

ClearMinds supports supervisor development through:

  • Funding or part-funding supervision training courses
  • Peer consultation groups for supervisors
  • Access to supervision literature and resources
  • Supervision of supervision arrangements
  • CPD opportunities in supervision practice

Clinical Supervision Support

Clinical Director: clinical.director@clearminds.com

For supervision queries: Discuss with your line manager or Clinical Director

To request additional supervision: Contact your supervisor or Clinical Director

To raise concerns about supervision: Speak to Clinical Director or HR in confidence

20. Policy Review

This policy will be reviewed:

  • Annually (minimum)
  • Following changes to professional body guidance on supervision
  • Following supervision-related incidents or complaints
  • Following CQC inspection feedback
  • Based on supervision evaluation feedback and audit findings

Supervision is Not Optional

Clinical supervision is a professional requirement and an essential safeguard for service users and therapists alike. It is not a sign of weakness to need supervision – it is a sign of professionalism, ethical practice, and commitment to quality. We all need supervision, regardless of experience. Good supervision makes good therapy possible.
